$BTC ü§ë Bitcoin's monthly timeframe price action ‚ÄîFebruary & March 2026

#Bitcoin #BTC #BTCUSDT

Let's look at what a green close means for February & March, what to expect when it comes to price action.

A positive close on the monthly session means the closing price is equal to or higher than the open. For example: Say January closes at $104,000. It can go higher during the month but by the time it closes the price is 104K. This is the open for February.

In February prices start rising and we get $110,000, $115,000 even $118,000 and so on. 13-February Bitcoin is at its highest, in this example can be any price between $114,000 to $120,000 or anything you think is possible. As the month reaches a close, prices start to go down. By the end of February we get $105,000 and the month ends.

See how in this example we get an open price of $104,000 and a close at $105,000 and we still get a green close on the monthly session. The upper wick would reach $114,000 or $120,000, whatever was the peak price.

But what about March?

It is the same. Let's assume we get a red close in March but this doesn't mean that the entire month we get bearish action. Say March opens at $105,000 and Bitcoin goes up to $112,000. Slowly but it gets there. Then it starts to go down, it fluctuates down and up but the month ends up closing at $100,000 and this gives us a red close. $105,000 the open vs $100,000 the close.

The ensuing months bearish momentum can intensify. This is all assuming we get a repeat of the last relief rally in 2022 which lasted two months.

These are just some examples to have an idea as to what we can expect. Whenever Bitcoin grows just a tiny bit, the altcoins will produce a strong reaction.

How to know when the bear market bottom is in?

When Bitcoin hits bottom, maybe after three months red after the end of the bullish period (five months total, three months for the intensity, steep decline and bearish momentum), we can know because of a major.

Key Drivers & Risks

Bearish Risks: Extreme overbought conditions and potential "Whale" profit-taking near $140k. Macroeconomic shifts or regulatory crackdowns remain the primary threats to the channel's stability.
Critical Support Zones
If Wave 4 extends below $90,000, watch these levels:
Primary ($84,000 ‚Äì $88,000): Most common Fibonacci retracement. A bounce here keeps the $140k target highly probable.
Secondary ($78,000 ‚Äì $81,000): Deep correction zone. Holding here keeps the count valid but suggests a slower recovery.
Line in the Sand ($68,000 ‚Äì $72,000): The "Must-Hold" Golden Pocket. Dropping below $68k invalidates the bullish impulsive count and may signal a long-term trend reversal.
Conclusion:
The technical outlook remains bullish with a target range of $120k‚Äì$150k. However, strict risk management and stop-loss orders are essential due to high volatility near cycle peaks.

$BTCOpportunities in AI, Crypto, and DePIN
Despite macro risks, clear growth opportunities remain. AI continues to drive productivity gains across industries, but sustainable growth requires scalable, real-world infrastructure.
This is where DePIN (Decentralized Physical Infrastructure Networks) plays a key role. DePIN enables decentralized compute, data, connectivity, energy, and payment infrastructure, turning crypto from speculation into practical utility. Combined with AI, it lowers costs, reduces reliance on centralized providers, and increases resilience.

$BTCMarket Update ‚Äì Slower Growth in Europe, Possible Rate Cuts
Recent data suggest that growth in the Eurozone in 2026 may be slightly weaker than expected, rather than accelerating as some hoped. According to the latest ECB projections (December 2025), real GDP growth is forecast at 1.2%, down from ~1.4% in 2025. Other forecasts are similar: OECD, Conference Board, Mastercard, and FT consensus around 1.2%, Allianz slightly lower at 1.1%, and Nomura expects gradual improvement later in 2026.
Signals supporting weaker growth:
Manufacturing PMI (Dec 2025): 48.8 ‚Äì deeper contraction, lowest in 9 months, with Germany performing worst, signaling industrial weakness that can drag the economy.
Composite PMI (Dec 2025): 51.5 ‚Äì still expansion, but declining from November ‚Üí growth slowing at the end of Q4.
Other risks:
US tariffs / trade wars impacting exports (cars, chemicals, machinery)
Fiscal tightening in France, Spain, Italy
Weak consumer demand, high savings, slower wage growth
Structural challenges: aging population, competition from China, EV transition
Positive factors include continued services growth (~52 PMI), low inflation (~1.9%), and fiscal support from Germany and NGEU funds. However, if manufacturing remains weak or trade frictions worsen, growth could fall closer to 0.8‚Äì1.0%.
Implications for rates and markets:
If growth slows faster than expected, the likelihood of additional ECB rate cuts in 2026 rises. Markets currently price little change, but a few disappointing data releases could change that quickly.
Investor takeaway: The scenario ‚Äúslower growth ‚Üí more cuts ‚Üí positive for markets‚Äù is still alive. Stay invested and hold your positions, as weaker growth with potential rate cuts generally supports financial markets.

Kaito shutting down Yaps is a structural shift, not just a bad headline.

The trigger is clear: X has cracked down on incentivized ‚ÄúInfoFi‚Äù apps to reduce spam. Yaps, which rewarded posting activity, depended on that API access. Once it was removed, the model broke.
The market reaction was immediate. KAITO sold off sharply because the token was closely tied to the Yaps incentive loop. When that loop ended, expectations had to reset.

What matters now is the pivot. Kaito is repositioning toward Kaito Studio, focusing on creator marketing, analytics, and curated distribution rather than post-to-earn mechanics. That‚Äôs a very different business model, with different token demand dynamics.

Key takeaway:

This isn‚Äôt a verdict on Kaito‚Äôs tech. It‚Äôs a reminder that platforms built on third-party social rails carry platform risk. The next phase for KAITO depends less on social incentives and more on whether the new model can generate real, recurring demand.
This is no longer an attention game. It‚Äôs an execution test.  $BTC

Japan is sitting on 10 trillion USD in debt and JGB yields just hit record highs.
They are preparing to sell 500 billion USD in US stocks to stabilize a system that is starting to break.
Japan survived only because rates were near zero. Now yields rise, debt payments explode and interest eats revenue.
No advanced economy escapes cleanly through default, restructuring or inflation.
The global risk comes from their foreign holdings.
Japan owns trillions abroad including more than 1 trillion USD in US Treasuries and massive equity positions.
When JGBs finally pay real returns and hedged Treasuries lose money, capital returns home.
This is simple math and it drains liquidity worldwide.
The yen carry trade is the second shock.
Over 1 trillion USD borrowed in cheap yen and pumped into stocks, crypto and emerging markets.
As Japanese rates rise and the yen strengthens, these positions unwind violently.
Forced selling spreads and margin calls hit across markets.
US and Japan yield spreads tighten.
Japan has less reason to keep money overseas and US borrowing costs rise regardless of Fed policy.
If the BOJ hikes again in January, the yen jumps and the unwind accelerates.
Risk assets feel it immediately including crypto and especially Bitcoin.
Japan also cannot print freely.
Inflation is already hot and more printing crashes the yen, lifts import costs and triggers domestic instability.
They are trapped between debt pressure and currency pressure with no clean exit.
For decades Japanese yields acted as the quiet anchor holding global rates down.
That anchor just snapped.
Bonds fall. Stocks fall harder. Crypto feels the deepest shock.
This is how everything looks stable until everything breaks at once.

$BTC is approaching a critical inflexion point
that could define the next phase of market structure. One key level to watch is the Short-Term Holder (STH) cost basis, which represents the average entry price of recent buyers.

A successful reclaim and hold above the STH cost basis would signal that short-term participants are back in profit. Historically, this tends to reduce sell pressure, improve sentiment, and create the conditions needed for momentum to re-accelerate as confidence returns to the market.

However, failure to reclaim this level keeps recent buyers underwater. In that scenario, upside attempts are more likely to face distribution, and price action typically remains choppy as the market continues working through a recovery phase rather than transitioning into a sustained expansion.

In short, the STH cost basis remains a key on-chain level to watch, acting as a line between recovery and renewed momentum for Bitcoin.
